stream_context.summary: Kaze spends most of this bonus stream building the second overworld segment (and sketching the third) for Return to Yoshi's Island.  Tasks include redistributing coins, devising an easier cliff-access route, planning the beach/ghost-ship/lighthouse sequence, and writing a new camera-angle/distance–based fog system on-stream.  He also vents about toolchain issues and recruits trusted beta testers for a separate FPS project.

development_findings.summary: Return to Yoshi’s Island’s overworld is divided into 15 parts; today Kaze focused on parts 2 & 3, aiming to add more easily collectable coins and a simpler route up a cliff via walkable rock formations.
development_findings.quote: “I want these to be easy to collect… and I fear some players won’t even understand what a wall-kick is.”

development_findings.summary: Part 3 will feature a beach with a ghost ship visible in heavy fog; the fog is cleared later by climbing a lighthouse and turning on its light, creating a ‘do something later to unlock something earlier’ mechanic.
development_findings.quote: “You walk up the lighthouse, turn the light, the fog disappears, and now you can enter the level.”

development_findings.summary: Kaze built a dynamic fog shader that increases opacity based on camera angle and distance to the ship; when the player gets too close, the screen fades to white and warps Mario back to shore until the lighthouse event is complete.

Most of SM64’s original engine has been replaced: custom rendering for coins, camera, skyboxes, quaternions instead of Euler angles, rewritten walking, swimming and collision.  Remaining vanilla pieces are Mario’s core action code and parts of the sound engine.
development_findings.quote: “Really it’s just Mario… the camera is 100 % custom code… coins aren’t even sprites anymore.”

development_findings.summary: Kaze is actively stripping out LibUltra and building his own N64 ‘operating system’ for performance and legal independence, aiming eventually to make a commercially sellable build.
development_findings.quote: “I’m working on reworking the operating system… I would have to change out Mario and the sound engine if I wanted this to be legally sellable.”

development_findings.summary: All skyboxes are now 3-D models; the original SM64 skybox system was removed because of visual quality limits.
He is considering embedding a minimal Python interpreter as a scripting layer, claiming that, for some cache-bound cases, it might outperform hand-written assembly on N64.
development_findings.quote: “Python can be faster than assembly… people would get so mad at me, that’s a perfect tweet.”

development_findings.summary: Design rationale: occasionally ‘less fun’ areas are kept intentionally to provide contrast and pacing within the game’s flow.
development_findings.quote: “Sometimes the part that people least like is also the part that’s most necessary to make the design work.”

context_findings.summary: Kaze distinguishes between commissioned hacks (e.g., Drug Boss Mario FPS) and passion projects; Return to Yoshi’s Island is purely passion-driven and thus free.
He feels his mental optimization has shifted from abstract math to game-design-specific problem solving, reflecting on aging and neural ‘specialization’.
context_findings.quote: “Sometimes I feel like my neurons just got more optimized… I’m bad at the things I used to be good at.”

context_findings.summary: Expressed frustration with NVIDIA Broadcast and OBS crashes, illustrating day-to-day technical friction in streaming and dev work.
Maintains a cautious beta-test policy, initially limiting access to long-time community members to avoid leaks.
context_findings.quote: “During the first beta testing I’m only going to accept people that have been here a long time because I want to minimize the chance of leaks.”

context_findings.summary: Philosophy on tooling: dismisses PC-port development, preferring original N64 hardware/emulation for authenticity and broad accessibility.
context_findings.quote: “Name one advantage to working on the PC port.”

biobak.summary: Responsible for graphical overhauls; Kaze repeatedly references waiting for Biobak’s ‘final rework’ of overworld parts to polish visuals.
biobak.quote: “Biobak is going to rework all levels here… after Biobak’s final rework we will probably do that.”

zeina.summary: Zeina briefly shared progress (likely animation or concept art), acknowledged by Kaze but with no detail provided.

key_stories.title: Building the Ghost-Ship Fog System
key_stories.summary: Kaze needs convincing volumetric fog around the ghost ship within N64 limits.  The vanilla fog can’t vary by area, so he codes a custom shader that scales alpha by camera angle and distance, then fades the screen and warps the player if they push through prematurely.
key_stories.challenge: Create localised, cinematic fog without killing performance.
key_stories.process: Wrote angle-aware fog macro, iteratively tweaked formulas live, added screen-wide fade and warp logic.
key_stories.outcome: Prototype works; still needs global skybox tweak and Biobak’s art pass.
key_stories.key_quote: “Our entire issue is that we want the fog to be around the ship – that’s the problem.”

key_stories.title: Replacing Nintendo’s Engine Code
key_stories.summary: To boost performance and avoid legal issues, Kaze is removing almost all first-party code.  He’s already replaced rendering, camera, physics helpers and is now rewriting the LibUltra-based OS.
key_stories.challenge: Dependence on proprietary Nintendo libraries and dated engine tech.
key_stories.process: Incremental subsystem rewrites (rendering, data structures, actions), planning full sound/OS replacement.
key_stories.outcome: Game now runs on a mainly custom engine; only Mario’s core actions and sound remain vanilla.
key_stories.key_quote: “If I wanted this to be legally sellable, I would have to update the sound engine and change out Mario.”

key_stories.title: Balancing Accessibility & Challenge in Overworld Coins
key_stories.summary: Early overworld segment lacked coins and required a wall-kick newcomers might not know.  Kaze re-examines the area, decides on walkable rock ‘steps’ and redistributes coins to guide exploration.
key_stories.challenge: Add collectibles without frustrating novice players.
key_stories.process: Discussed movement teaching signs, considered player skill gaps, planned terrain tweaks and coin placement.
key_stories.outcome: Design decision logged; implementation pending art pass.
key_stories.key_quote: “I want a simpler way to get up there because some people won’t even understand what a wall-kick is.”
